item.title: Alexey Guzey
item.description:
Alexey Guzey on Twitter

‚Äú.@gothamchess https://t.co/T4Hhbv4KoX says that AlphaZero really loves sacrificing pieces for speed & initiative. ‚ÄúAZ loves suppressing movement.‚Äù Web-based stockfish thinks AZ does dumb moves. Why? Because SF evaluates piece adv. If you zoom out, ‚Äúdumb moves‚Äù are actually smart.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/alexeyguzey/status/1561429769689960453

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022 - AI supplement

item.title: Jon Askonas
item.description:
Jon Askonas on Twitter

‚ÄúShort written assignments are FINISHED pedagogically. Educators need to wake up to this reality. There are alternatives: in-class blue books, oral exams, longer research papers (for now). But AI forces us to rethink our pedagogy. This took me 10 seconds in GPT-3.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/JonAskonas/status/1562074612866883584

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022 - AI supplement

item.title: Mark Tenenholtz
item.description:
Mark Tenenholtz on Twitter

‚ÄúDALLE-2 was paywall-released recently by an extremely well-funded company. Just yesterday, a group of independent researchers released their own model (Stable Diffusion) that you can use in a few lines of code for FREE. The speed of the ML research community is insane ü§Ø‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/marktenenholtz/status/1562047032172326912

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022 - AI supplement

item.title: Genel Jumalon ‚úàÔ∏è Collect-A-Con Kansas City
item.description:
Genel Jumalon ‚úàÔ∏è Collect-A-Con on Twitter

‚ÄúTL;DR ‚Äî Someone entered an art competition with an AI-generated piece and won the first prize. Yeah that‚Äôs pretty fucking shitty.‚Äù

‚ÄúReminded of what John Carmack said recently -- if no Elon, we won‚Äôt get to Mars anytime soon, because SpaceX‚Äôs existing business is lucrative and scalable and the Mars thing won‚Äôt make financial sense for a very long time. It‚Äôs only going to happen because he‚Äôs pushing for it‚Äù

item.title: Nathan Baugh
item.description:
Nathan Baugh on Twitter

‚ÄúRemember the copywriting Apple used to get consumers to opt out of ad tracking? Well, their own ask to track you reads quite different (h/t @sethmills21). Bonus points for the highlighted ‚ÄúTurn on personalized ads‚Äù üôÑ‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/nathanbaugh27/status/1560247262042791936

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022

item.title: Nathan Baugh
item.description:
Nathan Baugh on Twitter

‚ÄúWhy the outperformance? Because of a quirk with iOS 14.5. The update prevents sharing of data between different parties (i.e. Facebook accessing data from other apps). It does not prevent the exchange of data within a single platform. Apple is that single platform.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/nathanbaugh27/status/1560247266153308161

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022

item.title: Nathan Baugh
item.description:
Nathan Baugh on Twitter

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt blame Apple. Their ad network will be a $10B+ rev stream. But it‚Äôs important to understand the tradeoffs. Apple: ‚Ä¢ Weaponized a narrative to harm competitors ‚Ä¢ Crushed small businesses in the process ‚Ä¢ Bolstered their ad biz And yes, they‚Äôre still using your data.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/nathanbaugh27/status/1560247267499573255

source: Best of Twitter - August 22-Sep 11, 2022

item.title: Nick Bloom
item.description:
Nick Bloom on Twitter

‚ÄúThe shift to WFH is the largest shock to labor markets in decades. Pre-pandemic WFH was trending towards 5% of days by 2022. Now WFH is now stabilizing at 30%, a 6-fold jump. In America alone this is saving about 200 million hours and 6 billion miles of commuting a week.‚Äù

URL: https://twitter.com/I_Am_NickBloom/status/1564236320259461120
